story:
All donations are very much appreciated. 

Everyone who makes a named minimum donation of £20 will be entered in to the raffle for a chance to win some fantastic prizes donated by some amazing local businesses. 

The closing date for raffle entries is Saturday 28th November 2020.  The raffle winners will be drawn on Sunday 29th November 2020.

My story.....Cancer stole my Mum from me when I was only 10 years old, my brothers were 4 and 13....she was just 39. My younger brother was only 6 weeks old when whilst walking with the pushchair my Mum's leg broke causing her to fall. She was diagnosed with bone cancer at the age of 34.

Her first hospital stay lasted 14 weeks.  Precious time when she should have been with her newborn baby and young family. She then bravely endured chemotherapy, radiotherapy and some of the most invasive prosthetic surgery carried out at the time to replace her knee and hip bones. She was a fighter! After a remission period of only 1 year, bone cancer struck again in her other leg and she lost her hard fought battle.

14th September this year marked 34 years since cancer took my mum away, and all the special times we should have shared together. She survived just long enough to see my little brother in his reception school uniform.

Cancer also tried to take my Dad away. He was just 27 when he developed Hodgkin's Lymphoma but fortunately in his case the radiotherapy was successful.

I was very close to my Auntie Maggie. She had 3 sons and I had 2 brothers so we enjoyed our 'girl's time' together. She helped to look after us during school holidays when we would go and stay with her. They felt very special times. I was only 14 when she developed an aggressive brain tumour and died shortly after. She was only 51.

I must also pay tribute to my Gran and Linda, who were such amazing women and the 'mother figures' in my life. Their kindness, strength, compassion and resilience knew no bounds, but unfortunately they both also lost their battles to cancer.

We will all have our own stories of how cancer has touched our lives. Cancer may attack an individual but the ripple effects for friends and families are wide spread and devastating.

Macmillan understand how cancer can affect people's lives - their health, money, job and family. They are there to support people through their darkest times. A Macmillan nurse costs £221 per day. If we can raise enough money to fund 2 days of essential support that would be amazing!

Thank very much you. 

Helen Xx

story:
I have decided to challenge myself to help Macmillan Cancer Support throughout the coronavirus pandemic. I can only imagine people with cancer are anxious about the impact of coronavirus on their treatment and care. Life presently is so challenging without having to worry additionally about being diagnosed or treated for cancer. 

Sadly cancer for me is all too familiar a disease. My father passed away 10 years ago from stomach cancer, and this past year my father in law has been dealing with treatment for colon cancer. Not to mention the many friends and family members I know who have also fought their own battles with this horrible disease.

As we move into lockdown 2 fitness and working out may not be at the forefront of everyone's mind. And even for those who do workout regularly motivation may be beginning to wane with the current closure of gyms. So myself and my friend came up with the idea of completing forty days of fitness to help others and ourselves stay committed to being healthy.

Throughout the first lockdown is when I began running. I have always been active and a member of the gym but I had never ran anywhere but on a treadmill. I began walking everyday for 5km, which slowly turned into running and eventually transformed into running 10km 4 to 5 days a week. 

I have decided to put my new found love for running to good use and start this campaign. I won't lie this is going to be a real struggle for me but I am determined to succeed.

I am challenging myself to something active every day, for forty days.

With the UK facing a second lockdown, gyms have had to close yet again. But this time it is cold and dark and wet outside, and it is more difficult to stay physically active. story:
Thank you for visiting my fundraising page! I want to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support because, like many big charities, their usual fundraising activities have been severely disrupted by the pandemic during which cancer patients (and their families) have really needed extra support. Also some of you may know I am an oncology outpatient and the Macmillan website has been a useful and reliable resource, as well as reassuring me that if I had had (or if I have in the future) an actual cancer diagnosis, there is so much help available to deal with everything.


So, to encourage you to donate to this very worthy cause, I have two services to offer up to you - cracker making workshops and gift consultation services!


CRACKER WORKSHOPS
Last year I made my own crackers in order to make them more easily recyclable and they were a big hit with friends and family. This year I thought I could share the know-how! I will be offering workshops via the medium of Zoom in early December so you just need to collect/acquire the essentials (paper, tape, snaps, toilet roll tubes, twine) and your preferred innards (hats, jokes, chocolates/trinkets) and I’ll coach you through how to make a banging cracker. The suggested donation for the workshop is £5.


GIFT CONSULTATION
Is there somebody in your life that you are struggling to think of a Christmas gift idea for? Do you need some fresh inspiration? Would you like a simple system to organise your gift shopping? Or are you just interested in hearing what I think you should absolutely never buy anyone for Christmas? If you answered yes to any of those, my gift consultation services are for you! We can sit down and have a nice chat over the phone or Zoom/Skype/similar and I’ll help you make some progress. The suggested donation for a gift consultation is £5.


If you make a donation, please leave me a comment telling me which option/s interested you. Also if you are not interested in the above, please still feel free to donate anyway! Visit

www.macmillan.org.uk

to find out more about the valuable help Macmillan provide.

Thanks for visiting our page.

We have decided to do away with the tacky gifts that you'd associate with Secret Santa, and to instead donate the money we'd usually spend on bubble bath and wine to something far more important; The British Heart Foundation. 

2020 hasn't been easy to any of us but The BHF need us more than ever. 

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. 

Spread the message, the festive cheer AND the community spirit - let's get all our families and friends involved for this great cause. 

Thanks everyone.

story:
Sadly, on 21st October 2020, Mike Stone passed away at Epsom General Hospital. As you all know, Dad had suffered from a number of varying illnesses over the last decade, but he always managed to overcome them. Sadly, his respiratory issues got too much this time and his circulation wasn’t strong enough to pull him through, once more. 

As a family, we have been touched by the number of people asking how they can pay their respects. As you will be aware, numbers at Dad’s funeral have been capped and some people are unable to attend. We are asking for people to support the British Heart Foundation as they are a wonderful charity who are trying to help people like Dad in the future. 

If you are able to support the BHF in Mike’s memory, our family would incredibly appreciative.

story:
Every year Mold Rugby Club raises money for the British Heart Foundation, in the form of a rugby tournament. 2019 was our 10th year, and so far we have raised over 30k.

Unfortunately, due to Covid-19, this years tournament had to be cancelled. As such we haven't managed to add to our total. With this in mind I am going to be completing a personal challenge along with a few friends to top up the pot.

On the weekend of the 29/30/31st of Jan 2021 we aim to complete the Welsh 3 peaks challenge, riding in between the mountains, in 24 hours. 

9397ft of ascent on hills
6890ft of ascent on roads
136.6 miles riding
24 hours

The reason we raise money, is in memory of my little brother.
The Ginger Warrior
He had a passion for life, and rugby, that was infectious. He never let his condition dictate what he could, or couldn't do.
We ride and climb for him.

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge weve faced in our 60 year history. And its led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, weve never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into groundbreaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the worlds biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we cant drop the ball now.

story:
The 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas Collection 

Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs 
this Christmas! 

During December the four-legged volunteers of the Rossendale Group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community.  

Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this 
festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships!  

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas.  

We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss, 
social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future. 

Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too. 

Thank you and Merry Christmas

story:
The 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas Collection 

Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs 
this Christmas! 

During December the four-legged volunteers of the Epsom Group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community.  

Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this 
festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships!  

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas.  

We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss, 
social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future. 

Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too. 

Thank you and Merry Christmas

story:
Help us raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs this Christmas! 

During December hundreds of our fundraising dogs across the UK would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at supermarket and street collections, Christmas fairs and festive coffee mornings. Our four-legged fundraisers support the 400+ fundraising groups across the UK from Glasgow to Plymouth and everywhere in between.

Due to the current situation, most of our fundraising groups will not be out collecting this festive season, and our four-legged fundraisers will be very much missed! We hope you will do your bit and help us as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships! Heres how you can join in: 

	Donate £12 and share our posts across social media nominating a friend, family member or colleague to  get involved

	Set up your own fundraiser on this page

story:
In May 2021, I will be taking on the massive challenge of running the London Landmarks Half Marathon. 

In June 2020 my mum, Debbie Pfister, passed away after a 17 year long battle with Breast Cancer. She was an incredible person and was so strong to the end. 

I was 11 when my mum was first diagnosed. She was initially given 12-18 months to live, but thanks to all the pioneering research of Cancer Research UK, we got 17 extra years with my mum. Whilst it will never be enough time, I’m so grateful that I got to grow up with her around. 

I want to raise as much money as possible to help all families get as much time as possible with their loved ones battling cancer. 

Before 2020 I had never run more than the 1000m I was forced to run at school (and even then I walked most of it...). I took up running during lockdown and it has helped my mental health so much during this awful time. I’ve never done a proper race before, so I’m excited and terrified to see how this goes!

Please give what you can. Your support will make a massive difference and really help me to make it to that finish line! Thank you so much.

Irelands unrivalled coasts and inland waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike. But the water remains an
unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

Keeping the RNLI lifeboat at Tramore maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to
that crew training and kit, and the euros start to add up. During the pandemic we have still been offering a lifesaving service and are continuing to raise vital funds. Currently we have had 26 call outs in 2020 to mid November.

We haven’t been able to take part in our traditional fundraising this year and rely on donations from the public to continue saving

story:
After years of an unhealthy lifestyle which resulted in Type 2 Diabetes and Sepsis, I decided to change my ways and find ways of pushing myself and facing my fears. From this I started getting out into the countryside and the mountains. This became a passion for me, and now I want to take this into life changing challenges that will help others. Snowdon is a place I fell in love with the moment I climbed it 3 years ago, and from then have taken every opportunity to climb it since. This then flicked a switch in my head of how I'd love to walk from my home to the summit using the countries countryside paths. This challenge should take me roughly 10 days, 10 days of aiming to walk 20 - 30 miles and 10 days of sleeping free under the stars. 

WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. charity.registrationNumber: 288701 (England and Wales) and SC039479 (Scotland)

story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. 

Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. 

It sounds normal and it should be.

story:
#AWheelyLongWay

St. Catharine's College students and staff are walking, running, swimming, cycling, and rowing the combined distance of 3,500 miles (5,600km) over the 50 days from 11th November to New Year. 

Not only is it important to keep active and fit through lockdown and the Christmas vacation, but it's ever more important - with COVID ravaging especially the poorest people of the world - to remember those that don't have the food, shelter, education, or medical care that we at Catz are so fortunate to have. 

That's why we the people of St. Catharine's College are travelling #AWheelyLongWay to raise funds for the Yemen crisis through CARE International.  

If you're a Catz student, staff member, Fellow, alumna or alumnus - join us! Email "jcr.president at caths dot cam dot ac dot uk" for information about how you can help or get involved. 

If you're willing and able to donate - please give what you can!
